rdf:Description.rdfs:label: Quercus robur
rdf:Description.ns5:abstract: Quercus robur, commonly known as common oak, pedunculate oak, European oak or English oak, is a species of flowering plant in the beech and oak family, Fagaceae. It is a large tree, native to most of Europe west of the Caucasus. It is widely cultivated in temperate regions elsewhere and has escaped into the wild in scattered parts of China and North America.
rdf:Description.ns2:taxonomy:
Quercus robur (from the Latin quercus , "oak" + robur "hardwood, oak wood, oak") was named by Linnaeus in Species Plantarum (vol. 2, p.996) in 1753. It is the type species of the genus and classified in the white oak section ( Quercus section Quercus ).
Quercus robur Latin quercus robur Linnaeus Species Plantarum Species Plantarum type species white oak Quercus Quercus
It has numerous common names, including "common oak", "European oak" and "English oak". In French, it is called "chêne pédoncule."
The genome of Q. robur has been completely sequenced (GenOak project); a first version was published in 2016. It comprises 12 chromosome pairs (2n = 24), about 26,000 genes and 750 million bp .
Q. robur bp
There are many synonyms, and numerous varieties and subspecies have been named.
The populations in Iberia, Italy, southeast Europe, and Asia Minor and the Caucasus are sometimes treated as separate species, Q. orocantabrica, Q. brutia Tenore, Q. pedunculiflora K. Koch and Q. haas Kotschy respectively.
Q. orocantabrica, Q. brutia Q. pedunculiflora Q. haas
citation needed citation needed citation needed Quercus × rosacea Bechst. ( Q. petraea x Q. robur ) is the only naturally-occurring hybrid,
but the following crosses with other white oak species have been produced in cultivation: Quercus × rosacea Quercus × rosacea Bechst. Q. petraea Q. petraea Q. robur
Q. × bimundorum ( Q. alba × Q. robur ) (two worlds oak) Q. × macdanielli ( Q. macrocarpa × Q. robur ) (heritage oak) Q. × turneri Willd. ( Q. ilex × Q. robur ) (Turner's oak) Q. × warei ( Q. robur fastigiata x Q. bicolor ). Q. × bimundorum ( Q. alba × Q. robur ) (two worlds oak) Q. × bimundorum Q. × bimundorum Q. alba Q. alba Q. robur Q. × macdanielli ( Q. macrocarpa × Q. robur ) (heritage oak) Q. × macdanielli Q. × macdanielli Q. macrocarpa Q. macrocarpa Q. robur Q. × turneri Willd. ( Q. ilex × Q. robur ) (Turner's oak) Q. × turneri Q. × turneri Willd. Q. ilex Q. ilex Q. robur Q. × warei ( Q. robur fastigiata x Q. bicolor ). Q. × warei Q. × warei Q. robur fastigiata Q. bicolor Q. bicolor There are numerous cultivars available, among which the following are commonly grown: 'Fastigiata', cypress oak, is a large imposing tree with a narrow columnar habit. 'Concordia', golden oak, is a small, very slow-growing tree, eventually reaching 10 m (33 ft), with bright golden-yellow leaves throughout spring and summer. It was originally raised in Van Geert's nursery at Ghent in 1843. 'Pendula', weeping oak, is a small to medium-sized tree with pendulous branches, reaching up to 15 m. 'Purpurea' is another small form, growing to 10 m, with purple leaves. 'Pectinata' (syn. 'Filicifolia'), cut-leaved oak, is a cultivar where the leaf is pinnately divided into fine, forward-pointing segments.
'Fastigiata', cypress oak, is a large imposing tree with a narrow columnar habit. 'Concordia', golden oak, is a small, very slow-growing tree, eventually reaching 10 m (33 ft), with bright golden-yellow leaves throughout spring and summer. It was originally raised in Van Geert's nursery at Ghent in 1843. Ghent 'Pendula', weeping oak, is a small to medium-sized tree with pendulous branches, reaching up to 15 m. 'Purpurea' is another small form, growing to 10 m, with purple leaves. 'Pectinata' (syn. 'Filicifolia'), cut-leaved oak, is a cultivar where the leaf is pinnately divided into fine, forward-pointing segments.
